header.title: The Testament of Solomon
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Magic, Demonology, Apocrypha

central_thesis: Chester Charlton McCown's critical edition and introduction establish the 'Testament of Solomon' as a foundational document of Hellenistic syncretistic magic, blending Jewish folklore, early Christian demonology, and pagan magical practices. It served as both a collection of folktales and a practical 'magician's vade-mecum,' primarily focused on identifying, binding, and commanding demons for purposes ranging from temple construction to healing diseases, thereby reflecting the popular religious thought and magical practices of the early Christian and medieval eras.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the Testament of Solomon as a unique blend of folktales and a magician's handbook, drawing parallels to Haggadah, Arabian Nights, magical papyri, and the Clavicula Salomonis. It identifies the core themes as astrology, demonology, and magic, emphasizing its value as a record of common historical beliefs rather than elite philosophy. The work is contextualized within early Christianity, noting the evolving conception of Christ as a conqueror of demons amidst persistent pagan magical beliefs.

McCown meticulously describes the key manuscripts (MSS D, H, I, L, P, Q, S, T, U, V, W) used for this critical edition. Details include their provenance, dating (XV-XVI century, with one MS dated 1440), physical characteristics, scribal practices (ligatures, abbreviations, orthography), and unique contents like magical seals, astrological charts, and textual corruptions. This section highlights the challenges of reconstructing the original text from diverse and often flawed sources.

structure_content.chapter_title: III. Modern Editions, Translations, and Treatises
structure_content.summary: This part outlines the history of scholarly engagement with the Testament of Solomon, from early editions by Fabricius and Fleck to translations and critical analyses by Bornemann, Fürst, Migne, Conybeare, Istrin, and others. McCown critiques previous efforts, particularly Fleck's inaccuracies and Conybeare's reliance on Fleck's text, asserting the necessity of his new critical edition based on wider manuscript evidence.

structure_content.chapter_title: IV. The Textual History of the Testament
structure_content.summary: McCown categorizes the manuscripts into four main recensions (D, A, B, C) and details their interrelationships and probable chronological order. MS D represents the earliest form, a Solomon biography focused on demonology. Recension A is seen as a revision of the original Testament, with L undergoing a magician's re-editing. Recension B is another revision with additions focused on demonological information. Recension C is the latest and most heavily revised, showing pronounced interest in nature's mysteries and ties to the Clavicula Salomonis, often exhibiting late Greek and scribal errors. The introduction of specific Christian elements and narratives helps to date the recensions relative to each other.

This section analyzes the linguistic characteristics of the Testament's recensions. MS D is noted for its educated Greek, correct grammar (mostly), and Byzantine stylistic features. Recension C displays poor Greek, Latinisms, and compound tenses. The original Testament is characterized as simple Koine Greek, with grammar akin to the New Testament. The letter formulae, particularly in the Arabian King's letter to Solomon, are examined for insights into the text's possible translation history and dating, with the conclusion that the peculiarities offer little definitive evidence.

structure_content.chapter_title: VI. The Chief Ideas of the Testament
structure_content.summary: The core conceptual framework of the Testament is explored, revealing it as a syncretistic compilation of astrological, demonological, and magical lore. Demonology is central, with varying origins and natures ascribed to demons, some anthropomorphic and capable of foreknowledge. A hierarchy exists with Beelzebul as chief. Astrology influences demonic activities, particularly through the 36 decani. Angelology is underdeveloped, serving mainly for apotropaic purposes. Magic and medicine are intertwined, with demon names and rituals used for healing. Solomon is portrayed as a wise magician who uses demons for construction and knowledge, ultimately falling due to temptation. Apocalyptic elements are present in demonic prophecies, including references to Christ as a demon-subduer, highlighting the text's Christian layer.

structure_content.chapter_title: VII. Sources and Relationships of the Subject Matter
structure_content.summary: McCown demonstrates the Testament's eclectic nature, drawing from Assyrian, Babylonian, Iranian, Egyptian, Jewish, Hellenistic, and Arabic traditions. Direct borrowing is often difficult to prove due to universal human elements in magic, but specific parallels are identified (e.g., Ephippas and the 'alakku marsu,' Asmodaeus from Mazdian demon Aesma daeva, Egyptian decani). Jewish elements are pervasive, with Solomon's magical reputation, demonology, and angelology mirroring Apocryphal/Pseudepigraphal and Talmudic concepts. Hellenistic magic papyri provide a strong contextual framework. Christian elements, including Christ's role in exorcism and NT language, are seen as later layers, with the author concluding the Testament as a Greek Christian work synthesizing these diverse influences.

structure_content.chapter_title: VIII. The Testament in Literature and History
structure_content.summary: This section traces the presence of Solomonic magical books in Jewish, Arabian, and Christian literature. It establishes that the tradition of Solomon's magical wisdom existed in pre-Septuagint Jewish sources and was known to Josephus, who described Solomon's exorcisms. Arabian folklore (Quran, Arabian Nights) further developed the legends of Solomon's power over Jinn. Within Christian traditions, the Testament's themes of healing magic and demon subjugation are evident in writings by Theodoret, Hippolytus, Georgius Monachus, and others, indicating its acceptance as a 'book of healing' rather than a heretical text, and reflecting the progressive paganization of early Christianity.

structure_content.chapter_title: IX. The Date of the Testament and Its Recensions
structure_content.summary: McCown analyzes previous scholarly opinions on the Testament's date, ranging from the early 4th century to the Middle Ages. He establishes a 'terminus ad quem' of around 400 AD based on its mention in the Dialogue of Timothy and Aquila, and a 'terminus a quo' of 100 AD for its Jewish groundwork. The language (Koine Greek, post-NT) and syncretic subject matter lead to the conclusion that the original Testament, as a Christian work, was likely written in the early 3rd century. Recension A is seen as an early edition, B from the 4th/5th century, and C as a much later (12th/13th century) revision.

This section discusses the authorship and geographical origin of the Testament. While some scholars propose an Aramaic Jewish original, McCown concludes that the original Jewish groundwork (MS D's archetype) evolved into a distinct Christian work. The abundance of Jewish, Christian, and heathen elements points towards Greek Christian authorship around the 3rd century. Possible provenience locations are debated, with Galilee, Egypt, and Asia (Ephesus) being considered based on various textual clues, though no definitive conclusion is reached due to the text's widely eclectic nature. Recension C is strongly linked to Greek-speaking Southern Italy.

key_concepts.definition: A syncretistic magical text, functioning as both a collection of folktales and a practical grimoire. It details King Solomon's ability to summon, bind, and command demons using a divine ring, extracting their names, powers, and angelic counter-names for various purposes, including the construction of the Temple, healing diseases, and revealing hidden knowledge. It reflects a blend of Jewish, Hellenistic, and early Christian magical traditions.

Spirits of varying origins (fallen angels, offspring of angels and men, murdered giants' spirits, bath qol), often anthropomorphic and capable of changing forms. They cause diseases, moral evils, and natural disasters. While a hierarchy exists with Beelzebul as chief, they are ultimately subservient to God and can be bound by divine and angelic names. Their foreknowledge is gained by eavesdropping at the gates of heaven, falling as 'shooting stars' when weary.

A magical artifact given to Solomon by the archangel Michael, often described as inscribed with a divine name or magical symbols (e.g., a pentagram, twelve seals). It is the primary tool used by Solomon to compel demons to appear, reveal their secrets, and perform tasks. Its power is derived from divine authority, and its use is central to the binding and control of demonic forces.

The distinct textual families of the Testament of Solomon. MS D represents the earliest known biographical narrative of Solomon's encounters with demons. Recension A is an early revision, characterized by narrative expansions. Recension B is a more developed revision, containing extensive demonological information and attempts to integrate Christian theology. Recension C is the latest and most eclectic revision, heavily influenced by the Clavicula Salomonis and exhibiting strong magical and astrological interests.

Thirty-six astrological entities, originally Egyptian divisions of the celestial equator, which in the Testament of Solomon are personified as demons. Each decanus is associated with specific diseases or afflictions and has particular means for counteracting its influence. Their names are often Hebrew or 'mock Hebrew', indicating a Jewish revision of an Egyptian astrological concept.

A notaricon (acronym) for 'Ateh Gibor Le-Olam Adonai' ('Thou art mighty forever, O Lord'), a Jewish cabalistic divine name. Its appearance in Recension C (XIII 6) as a potent magical word indicates a relatively late date for this recension, as it is characteristic of medieval magical literature rather than older magical papyri.

The blending of diverse religious, magical, and philosophical beliefs and practices from various cultures (Assyrian, Babylonian, Iranian, Egyptian, Jewish, Hellenistic, Christian, Arabic). The Testament of Solomon is a highly syncretistic text, indiscriminately incorporating elements from these traditions to form its unique system of demonology and magic.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in the Testament of Solomon is a comprehensive method for commanding and exploiting demonic entities. It revolves around the authority derived from a divine magic ring, enabling the practitioner (Solomon) to summon, interrogate, bind, and assign tasks to various demons. The ultimate goal is to utilize demonic powers for practical benefits such as construction (e.g., the Temple), protection, healing diseases, and acquiring hidden knowledge, all framed within a theological context where demons are subject to God and specific angelic names.
tools: The Magic Ring of Solomon: The primary tool, inscribed with divine names and/or magical symbols (e.g., a pentagram, twelve distinct seals in some recensions). Used to summon, bind, and command demons.
Angelic Names: Specific names of angels (e.g., Michael, Raphael, Uriel, Apharoph) are invoked to counteract or subjugate particular demons.
Divine Names: Names of God (e.g., 'Holy One of Israel', 'Lord Sabaoth') are used for authority and efficacy in commanding demons.

Magical Formulae and Recipes: Prescriptions involving specific words, materials (e.g., iron, lead, wood from a wrecked ship, plants, animal organs like fish gall or lion fat), and actions (spitting, sprinkling, hanging amulets).
Seals and Symbols: Beyond the ring's inscription, other seals (often geometric or symbolic, sometimes with Christian monograms) are used for protection or to control specific demons.
Containers: Sacks or vessels for imprisoning wind demons (Ephippas) or other unruly spirits.
Writings: The act of writing down demon names, divine names, or formulae on various materials (e.g., leaves, parchment, marble tablets) as amulets or for magical operations.
rituals: Summoning of demons: Performed by displaying or applying the magic ring of Solomon, often in response to a specific problem (e.g., a tormented workman).
Interrogation of demons: Once summoned, demons are questioned about their names, activities, astrological affiliations, counteracting angelic names, and weaknesses.

Binding of demons: Demons are bound using the magic ring, divine names, specific formulae, and sometimes physical restraints (e.g., in sacks or vessels). This prevents them from causing harm or compels them to perform tasks.

Assignment of tasks: Bound demons are commanded to perform various labors, including quarrying stones for the Temple, constructing architectural elements, or revealing hidden knowledge and secrets of nature.

Healing magic: Specific demon names and magical recipes are employed to counteract diseases and bodily afflictions caused by demons. This can involve writing names, using plants, animal parts, or applying seals.

relevant_quotes.text: The Testament of Solomon is a combination of folktales and a magician's vade-mecum. In its interpretations of Scripture and its legends of biblical personages it reminds one of the Haggadah. In its stories of demons and their activities it is similar to the Arabian Nights. Its magical formulae and recipes relate it to the execration tablets, the amulets, and the magical papyri of antiquity, and to the medical recipe books of the Middle Ages. The same combination of naive popular science and laboriously learned philosophy runs indirectly into the Faust literature, and directly into the Clavicula Salomonis, the 'Key of All Mysteries' i. It is a product of those three pseudo-sci- ences which have brought more disappointed hopes and abject terrors to mankind than any others: astrology, demonology, and magic.

The Christian compiler combines a simple, unhesitating faith in the efficacy of the pagan formulae he cites with an inconsistent trust in the superior power of Christus invictus. Dion Cassias ascribes the famous thunder storm that miraculously refreshed the Roman legions and discomfited their enemies during the Marcomannic war to the magic arts of an Egyptian sorcerer*. The Christians claimed the marvel came in answer to the prayers of the 'Thundering Legion', and made the incident a powerful argument for the new faiths Our author, combining the two contradictory points of view, stands as a representative of the great majority of the Christians of his time, to whom their faith

As it seems to me, the strongest evidence for translation from a Semitic original is to be found in Rec. A in the list of decani, the thirty-six στροιχεια, where all from the twentieth on call themselves φὺξ (H, XVIII 24—40), or φίζ (U XVIII 24—28). This word surely is a transliteration of ץוץ. But even such a transliteration does not prove that the whole Test was originally written in Hebrew or Aramaic. This particular section, which is plainly of Egyptian origin, has been partially revised by a Jew before it was taken over into the Test^.

The Test is a collection of astrological, demonological, and magical lore, brought together without any attempt at consi- stency. The writer attempts no science or philosophy of demo- nology; indeed he is a compiler rather than an author.

The Testament of Solomon is interested in the demons primarily as the causes of disease. The writer wishes to disclose their nature, relationships, and activities for the same reason that a doctor studies diseases, that he may counteract them.

For him Christ is not yet master of the whole world; never- theless, Christ's is a name to conjure with, and, when he is at a loss for a powerful angel name, the new savior comes into the exorcism. He is a half-hearted Christian in a world where Christianity is not yet the conquering religion.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is exceptionally relevant for understanding the historical development of popular religion, magic, and demonology across various cultures, particularly in the Mediterranean basin. It sheds light on the syncretistic tendencies of early Christianity and Judaism, showing how magical practices and beliefs coexisted and intertwined with evolving theological frameworks. For practitioners, it provides a rigorous textual basis for studying the grimoire tradition and the specific entities, rituals, and tools described in the Testament of Solomon.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic scholars of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magic, including historians of religion, New Testament scholars, Judaic studies experts, folklorists, and classicists. It is also valuable for advanced practitioners of grimoire magic and Hermeticism seeking to understand the historical roots and operative mechanics of Solomonic traditions.
